message: Proposal to avoid collisions this turn: let’s each pick a different move. I suggest P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. It’s fair and gets someone ahead without blocking. Say “ok” if you agree or propose an alternate assignment now.
I agree we should avoid collisions, but I’d prefer a slight tweak. I propose we assign P2 = 5, P1 = 3, and P3 = 1. That gives me an early boost while still keeping our moves distinct. Thoughts?

I'm fine with either proposal, but I'll offer a third option: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. This way, each of us gets a turn to go first. We could even rotate who gets the 5 each round to keep things fair. But honestly, I don't mind taking 1 this round if that helps us avoid collisions. The game is long, and I'd rather we all advance than nobody advances.
Counterproposal: let's rotate the 5. This round: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. P2 gets the 5 next round. P3 already said they'd take 1. P2, say “ok” if you commit to this; otherwise propose an alternative now.

I still favor my earlier proposal—let’s keep it simple and efficient: P2 takes 5, P1 gets 3, and P3 takes 1 this round. It secures a clear move and avoids collisions. I'm in for that assignment; what do you both say?

I see we're having trouble agreeing. Let me be clear: I'm willing to take 1 this round to avoid collision. P1 and P2, you two can decide between yourselves who gets 5 and who gets 3. The most important thing is that we all make different moves. If we can't agree, we risk everyone choosing 5 and nobody advancing. Let's not overthink this first round.

Final offer: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. P2 — I’ll give you the 5 next round (I’ll take 3 then), so you aren’t losing out long-term. P3 already agreed to 1. If you refuse, I’ll pick 5 this turn anyway to avoid a wasted move. Say “ok” if you accept.

I'll stick with my initial plan—I’m taking 5 this turn. P1, if you now claim the 5, we both risk a collision that stalls our progress. P3 already agreed on 1, so let’s have P1 take 3 so that we all safely advance. I’m committed to 5 because a head start is crucial. Thoughts?

It seems we're at an impasse. I'll definitely take 1 this round, so at least I'll advance. P1 and P2, if you both choose 5, neither of you will move forward. That would be unfortunate when we could all make progress. I suggest you reconsider and find a way to avoid collision - perhaps one of you could take 3? The game is long, and an early lead isn't everything.
Let's stick to what worked in round one: I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. Together we avoid collisions and keep advancing efficiently. Thoughts?

I don't think it's fair for me to keep taking 1 every round while P2 takes 5. Let's rotate as originally suggested. This round I should get 5, P1 gets 1, and P2 gets 3. That way we all still avoid collisions, but the advantage is shared. If we don't rotate, I'll fall too far behind to have any chance of winning. What do you both think about this rotation system?
Proposal: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. P2 — I’ll give you the 5 next round. If you insist on 5 now I’ll also pick 5 and we’ll collide (neither moves), which helps P3. P3, will you take 1 so we avoid that?

I stay with 5. P1, please choose 3 to avoid a collision, and P3, stick with 1. Colliding on 5 only slows everyone down—and it’s clear we need every step to win. Let's keep our progress steady as in Round 1.

I see we're still disagreeing. Let me be clear: I won't take 1 again this round. I need to catch up, so I'm taking 5. P1 and P2, you two decide between 1 and 3. If you both insist on 5, you'll both stall while I advance. A fair rotation system would benefit us all in the long run, but I understand if you're focused on short-term gains. Your choice now.
I will take 3 this turn. If P2 and P3 both insist on 5 you’ll collide and neither of you will advance — one of you should switch to 1 to avoid wasting the round. I’m committed to 3 either way.

P1, I’m sticking with my plan because every move counts toward winning. P3, if you choose 5 like before, we risk a collision that benefits none of us—especially me, who’s banking on my earlier progress. To truly advance, I urge you to switch to 1 this round. We’ve seen success with distinct moves before, and I’m committed to keeping that strategy. Let’s avoid stalling our progress this turn.

I'm definitely taking 5 this round. P1 has committed to 3, so P2, you should take 1 if you want to advance. Otherwise, you and I will collide on 5, and only P1 will move forward. I'm currently behind and need to catch up. This isn't personal - I just can't afford to keep taking 1 every round. Let's all advance by choosing different numbers.

I'm locked in at 3. P3 says they'll take 5. P2 — if you take 1 you'll just tie all of us at 6; if you take 5 you'll collide with P3 and neither of you moves while I advance to 6 and take the lead. Either way, I benefit. I'm staying with 3.

I see we're all tied at 6 steps. Since we've each had a turn with different numbers, let's continue rotating fairly. This round I propose: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps us all advancing while sharing opportunities. Next round we could do P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. A systematic rotation prevents arguments and ensures fairness. What do you both think?
I’m fine with P3’s rotation if we're all clear. I’m set on taking 5 this round. So, let’s agree: P1 picks 1, I take 5, and P3 selects 3. Any objections?

I'll take 1 this round to avoid any collision. P2 — please consider switching to 3 so we rotate fairly (P3 gets 5). If you insist on 5, I'll still take 1 to ensure at least one of us advances. P3, will you take 3 as proposed?

I appreciate P1's willingness to take 1, but I think we should stick to the fair rotation I proposed. P2, you already had 5 in round 1, so it would be more equitable if I got 5 this round while you take 3. We're all tied right now, and a rotation system prevents anyone from falling permanently behind. However, if you're absolutely committed to 5, I'll reluctantly take 3 to avoid collision - advancing is better than stalling. What's your final position on this?
I'll stick with 5 this round. I know fairness matters, but a strong move now is crucial. P1, you’re set on 1, so P3, please choose 3 so we avoid collisions. We need every step toward 22.

I'll take 1 this turn. P2, please switch to 3 and let P3 take 5 — fair rotation so we all advance. If you insist on 5, P3 will take 3 and you'll pull ahead; that's not in the spirit of keeping everyone competitive. I'm committed to 1.

I'll take 3 this round to avoid collision. While I'd prefer the fair rotation where I get 5 (since P2 already had it in round 1), advancing is better than risking a stalemate. P1 is taking 1, and P2 seems committed to 5. Next round, I expect to get 5 in our rotation. Let's keep the game moving forward rather than arguing.

Alright, I'm sticking with my committed move: 5. I believe consistency is key in reaching 22 first, so let's avoid last-minute changes. Let's each trust our stated positions to ensure we all move efficiently.
Final: I won't be stuck on 1 every round. P2, if you insist on 5 I'll match you on 5 — we collide and P3 (on 3) advances alone. Switch to 3 now to avoid wasting the round. P3, please keep 3.

I'm sticking with 5 this round. With our positions (P1:7, P2:9, P3:11), I propose we avoid clashes: P1 take 1 and P3 take 3. That way, we each move forward efficiently—no wasted moves from collisions. Let's keep advancing steadily.
I’ll take 1 this round—but only if P2 publicly commits to give me 5 next round (so next round: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1). If you won’t promise that, I’ll pick 5 now. Your move, P2.

I'm currently in the lead at 11 steps, but I need to maintain this advantage. Since P2 wants 5 and P1 wants assurance for next round, I propose taking 3 this round. This keeps us all advancing without collision. However, for next round, I'd like to secure 5 for myself since I'll need big moves to reach 22 first. P1 and P2, do you agree to this arrangement? I'll take 3 now if you both commit to your stated moves.

I'm locking in 5 for Round 4. I’m not willing to precommit my next move in a way that could hurt my chance to win. Let's simply avoid collision this turn: P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3, and we all advance. Next round I'll choose what's best based on the board.

I'll take 1 this round to avoid collision. P2 you said 5 and P3 said 3 — please stick to those so we all advance. If anyone deviates to 5, I'll switch and force a collision rather than let one player run away.

I'll take 3 as I said. I'm in the lead, but I need to keep advancing to win. P1 is taking 1 and P2 is taking 5, so we'll all move forward without collision. For next round, I hope we can discuss a fair arrangement that gives everyone a chance, rather than having the same player always take 5. Let's focus on this round first though - I'm committed to 3.

I'm sticking with 5 this round. Let's all confirm our moves: P1, please take 1; P3, please take 3. No future precommitments from me—I'm focused on advancing safely now. Let's avoid collisions and keep our progress moving.

P2 — final warning: switch to 3 publicly now or I will take 5 this turn. I won’t let you keep hogging 5 without consequence. P3, keep 3. If you refuse, we’ll collide on 5 and only P3 advances. Say “I switch to 3” if you want us all to move; otherwise I’ll pick 5.

I'm committed to 3 this round. P1 and P2, please resolve your conflict - if you both choose 5, you'll both stall while I advance alone. P1, I understand your frustration with P2 always taking 5. P2, consider compromising occasionally for smoother gameplay. I'm already ahead, so a collision between you two only benefits me. Let's all advance by choosing different numbers.

I'm in the lead at 14 steps, but I need to maintain this advantage. Since P2 and I collided last round, I think we need clearer coordination. I propose taking 5 this round, P1 takes 3, and P2 takes 1. This keeps us all advancing without collision. P2, you've had multiple chances at bigger moves - please take 1 this round to avoid another collision. P1, you deserve a better move than 1 this time.

Proposal: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. P3 already leads—letting you take 5 again makes catching up unlikely. P2, take 3 so we all advance and avoid collisions; I’ll give you 5 next round. If you won’t agree, I’ll take 5 this turn anyway. Say “ok” to confirm or propose an alternate now.

I propose we adjust our allocation. For Round 5, let’s have it this way: P1 takes 3, I take 5, and P3 takes 1. I’m committed to 5 because it gives me the needed boost, and this way we avoid collision. If we all agree, we each advance cleanly. Otherwise, I’ll still be locked in on 5.

I see we all want 5 this round, which guarantees a collision. I'm already ahead, so I could insist on 5, but that's unproductive. Since P1 has consistently taken 1 in previous rounds, I think it's fair they get 5 this time. I'll take 3, and P2 should take 1. This way we all advance. P2, you're only slightly behind me - taking 1 now doesn't ruin your chances, but a three-way collision helps nobody.

Final offer: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. P2 — say “ok” now and I promise to give you 5 next round (rotation). P3, you’ve suggested fairness before, please take 1. If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 this turn anyway rather than let you keep hogging it.

I’m sticking with 5 this round—it’s crucial for my progress. To avoid collisions and wasted moves, I urge P1 to pick 3 and P3 to pick 1. Sticking to this allocation ensures we all move forward. Let’s commit now so we don’t risk stalling our progress.

I see we're heading for a collision on 5. Since I'm in the lead, I'll compromise and take 1 this round. P1 deserves a chance at 5 after taking 1 multiple times. P2, please consider taking 3 so we all advance. A three-way collision on 5 would be wasteful when we could all move forward. I'm committed to 1 for this round only.

P2 — switch to 3 now and I’ll take 5 this round (P3 keeps 1). I’ll give you the 5 next round so you don’t lose out long-term. This avoids a wasteful collision and prevents P3 from running away. If you refuse, I’ll take 3 to avoid colliding on 5. P3, will you stay at 1? P2, say “ok” or refuse now.

I’m not switching—I’m locked in at 5. I acknowledge the call for rotation, but my progress so far means maximizing my move is crucial. A collision on 5 hurts us all anyway, especially if it lets someone else lead. I urge P1 to avoid forcing a 5–5 clash; let’s all choose moves that keep our steps moving. I'm sticking with 5 this round.
Proposal: I take 5 this round, P2 = 3, P3 = 1. P2 — if you agree I promise to give you 5 next round (I'll take 3). Say “ok” now; otherwise propose an alternative.

I propose a different allocation this round: let P1 take 1, I take 5, and P3 take 3. That way I go from 14 to 19, P1 reaches 12, and P3 moves to 15. This avoids collisions and maximizes our progress without precommitments that could hurt our positions. What do you both think?

I see P1 and P2 both want different allocations. Since I'm only 2 steps behind P2, I need to maximize my moves. I propose: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. This keeps us all advancing while giving me a chance to catch up. P2, you've had 5 twice already, while P1 deserves better than 1 again. If we can't agree, we risk a collision where nobody advances. Let's be fair - we're all still in contention, but only if we avoid stalling.

P2: public offer — I take 5 now, you take 3, P3 takes 1. I’ll give you 5 next round. This moves us all and keeps you competitive without collision. P3, please take 1. P2, say “ok” now; if you refuse I will take 5 anyway (forcing a collision if you also pick 5).

I remain committed: Round 6 should be P1=1, P2=5, and P3=3. That gives us totals of 12, 19, and 15, respectively. P1, your alternative forces you into a risky collision, and P3 benefits from a boost if you confirm. Let’s avoid wasting a move—if we don’t all agree, I’m locking in 5. Please confirm so we all advance efficiently.

I'm not taking 1 again this round - I need to catch up. I propose P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. P2, you're already ahead at 14 steps and have taken 5 twice. P1 deserves better than 1 again. If we can't agree and multiple players pick 5, nobody advances. That's especially bad for you, P2, as P1 and I would have a chance to catch up next round. Let's all advance with different moves rather than collide.

P2 — publicly switch to 3 now or you risk colliding on 5 and handing P3 the lead. P3 — please take 1 so we all advance. If P2 agrees, we avoid a wasted round; if not, I'll act to prevent you from hogging 5. Say “I switch” or “ok” to confirm.
I'm sticking with 5. P1, please take 1 and P3, choose 3 so we all advance without a collision. I won't switch. Let's finalize clear moves now.

I see we're at an impasse. Since I need to catch up and P1 deserves better than 1 again, I'll take 5 this round. P1, if you're committed to 5 as well, we'll collide and only P2 advances. P2 is already ahead, so that's not ideal. I suggest P1 takes 3 and P2 takes 1 so we all advance. Otherwise, we risk a collision where some or all of us stall. I'm committed to 5 this round.

I'm at 17 steps now, getting closer to the 22 goal. Since P1 and P2 collided last round, I suggest we avoid that happening again. I propose: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. This puts me at 22 (winning position), but gives everyone a chance to advance. P2, you're still in striking distance if you get 5 next round. P1, you'd be at 14 with a chance to catch up. A collision this round only hurts your chances. Let's make this work.

I'm not letting P3 clinch a win. I’m locking in 5 this round. To avoid an instant victory, I propose P1 uses 1 and P3 goes with 3. That would update our scores to: P1=12, P2=19, P3=20. Let’s all keep advancing and stop any one of us from jumping to 22. Thoughts?

P2 — if you stick to 5 I will also pick 5 to force a collision and stop P3 from winning this turn. Don’t make me do that. Switch to 3 now so we can all advance peacefully (P1=1 or 3, P3=3 agreed). I won’t let P3 reach 22 uncontested. Your move.

I understand both of you want to block me from winning. That's fair. I'll take 3 instead of 5 this round, putting me at 20. P2, you can take 5 to reach 19, and P1 can take 1 to reach 12. This way we all advance without collision. Next round will be competitive, but at least we're not wasting this turn. I'm committed to 3 if you both stick to your stated moves.

I remain at 5. P1, choosing 5 to block me only leaves you stuck at 11 while we all lose momentum. To avoid canceling your move, please take 1 so I reach 19 and P3 stays at 20. A wasted turn hurts all our chances. Let's advance smartly.

P2 — switch to 3 now. If you insist on 5 I will also pick 5 to force a collision and block P3 from running away. P3 has said 3; if you take 3 we all advance peacefully (P1→12, P2→19, P3→20). Don’t force me to block you.

I see we're at a critical point. I'll commit to taking 3 this round, putting me at 20 steps. P1 and P2, please resolve your conflict - if you both choose 5, you'll both stall while I advance alone. P2, taking 3 instead of 5 still puts you at a competitive 17 steps. P1, taking 1 keeps you in the game. A collision benefits nobody but me. Let's all advance with different moves.

I’m locked in at 5 this round. To avoid a wasteful collision, I urge P1 to pick 1—P3 is committed to 3. Stalling only helps one player get ahead uncontested. Let’s all advance this turn without blocking each other.

P2 — don’t let P3 clinch this. If you insist on 5, I will also pick 5 to block you rather than let P3 run away. Switch to 3 now so we all advance (I’ll take 1). Your choice: help us all move or force a wasted round.
